snippet: A new breed of landlord is blurring the line between renter and homeowner, but these firms claim they’re bringing homeownership to those who can’t get mortgages....
abstract: Investigation by The New York Times reveals that increasingly popular rent-to-own contracts on homes are more risky than they appear to be as they reside in gray area of law and lack consumer protections; contracts have gained in popularity as lenders have stopped offering mortgages for homes worth less than $100,000.

byline.original: By ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN

lead_paragraph: A new breed of landlord is blurring the line between renter and homeowner, but these firms claim they’re bringing homeownership to those who can’t get mortgages.

headline.main: Rent-to-Own Homes: A Win-Win for Landlords, a Risk for Struggling Tenants
headline.print_headline: Renting to Own Gains in Favor, and Risks Rise
